What a great tablet. Easy to use and durable. I bought this tablet to use as a video source for a teleprompter and it works great. The android store offers a variety of teleprompter apps (many are free!) and it has been awesome. I chose this tablet because it is the same dimensions as the Apple Ipad (which is needed for my teleprompter) but at half the cost. I am very satisfied. In addition,  I use it all the time for searching the web, watching Youtube videos, sending emails, and streaming NETFLIX. It does an excellent job of streaming, never choppy or rebuffering. It plays clean. With the removable micro SD card (sold separately) I copied about 15 full length movies to watch while on vacation and it held up. It has a long battery life and my kids used the tablet for hours on end watching movies while I was driving. I've never had a problem with this tablet freezing up, turning off, overheating, acting weird in any way. It's been solid. Tech savvy kids and not-so-savvy adults can use this tablet easily and often. Everyone loves it.

My only criticisms and they are very minor: 1) The audio Up/Down controls are a little hard to use even when I know how. The buttons are built so close the body of the tablet it's kind of hard turning the volume up and down, but this is really no big deal.  2) The movies I copied onto the SD card  would play choppy if they were Blue Ray rips. This tablet could not handle a Blue Ray rip. It did fine with AVI, MPEG4, HD, SD, 1080, 720 etc. It just couldn't handle a Blue Ray rip. But again, no big deal. Buy it. Buy it now.

Don't buy this.  I mean, the fact that you CAN'T buy it on Amazon anymore should put a damper on that, but if you happen to be searching for reviews before buying it from someplace else (like a guy in a van who is also selling meat and stereos) keep in mind that this thing fails on so many levels it's mind-bottling.  (Not mind-boggling, I mean it practically converts your mind into diet cola and bottles it.)

One entire side of the screen stopped responding to touch input.  The reset switch (the one accessed through a hole on the back of the thing) stopped working.  It took maybe five tries to get my flash card to get recognized, and occasionally it would stop showing up, making the tablet useless until it decided to start working again.  The battery's connection to the board is awful so it occasionally stops charging and you have to open the thing to reconnect it.  The power button isn't soldered to the main board very well so some owners (such as my lucky self) have had to bust out our soldering irons or reflow tools to fix it.  Le Pan's technical support for the thing was utterly nonexistent even when the thing was the only product they made, and now they appear to have forgotten the thing ever existed at all.  The only high note was that it set my standards for tablets so incredibly low that my new Jelly Bean-running tablet seems like a cross between Superman and the Messiah.

Oh, and speaking of Android versions, Le Pan once stated that the 2.2-running TC 970 would be upgradeable to newer versions.  And technically they were telling the truth, but only because they apparently considered "buying a newer model of tablet" to be upgrading.

I was reading through the reviews for this product and found them fairly mixed, so I decided to add my experience. I've had my Le Pan 970 I for almost two years. Other than that, I've been very pleased with my tablet. I primarily use it for internet surfing, reading news and beaming video to a Roku via the Twonky app. It's been incredibly reliable and easy to use. Yes, you will occasionally come across an app that acts a little buggy. No, you will not be able to replace a desktop with this device. You probably won't want to edit video, write long documents or create media presentations using this device. But I have a desktop and a laptop for those needs. If you want an easily portable media device for internet surfing, reading books/comics or displaying photos on the go, this tablet is great. Using the SD slot, storage is a cheap upgrade.

There are absolutely better tablets on the market. There are faster, more powerful and easier to use options out there. And those options cost at least 2-3 times what the Le Pan costs. That's a trade-off you'll have to decide for yourself.

I love my new Le Pan II. The quality, the build, the features for this price is great. If you just want simple, however, it may not appeal to you.

The Le Pan is a bit of an odd duck, with some of its Ipad-ish qualities. One port for power/usb/HDMI ... can take some getting used to. I have been finding out, however, that just because it doesn't work the way I'm used to, that does not mean it can not be done. I just have to step up my tech.

Can't grab a usb flash drive and transfer data? Ok, fine - I found an app and now can transfer my data wirelessly on my home network.

Movies won't play? Nope, don't re-rip or convert - find another app.

Can't find any movies through the Google Apps? That's because the Google store sees Le Pan II as.. something far less. What, I'm not sure. But use Chrome, go to the Google Store page, sign in there, browse, buy, add to your list, and then - it's there in your Play Movie app and you can watch it. (Just find a free preview to test run.)

Need to update all those compatible apps that came on it, that Google store says isn't compatible? Well, the standard ones that were included tend to be free and therefore are in 1Mobile Market and you can use 1Mobile Market's app to update them.

To be honest, the 2 most frustrating things are Google Play's oh so helpful (not) feature that treats all information they've deemed incompatible invisible. Much better would be Amazon's method where you can see, read about and study all items they sell.. but that shows a "Not compatible with device" warning. The invisible Google way leaves many people clueless that something does exist. And unable to research options. Including the option - I need a different device. The second huge headache has nothing to do with Le Pan and affects all tablets. It was finding out a change in Xfinity's tablet protocol that I've yet to find an app to deal with.

I keep hoping Google Play will get it together and reassign LePan II's status, because right now I think its sitting at Gingerbread or something. But until that happens, many tablet users aren't going to want to deal with the annoying work-arounds. And yes, there is 1Mobile Market and Amazon, but 1 doesn't carry anything that isn't free and some people may have noticed, Amazon doesn't carry a huge selection of apps that may directly compete with them.

I love my Amazon, its my go-to place. I have Amazon shortcuts on my laptop and tablet, but, I want full access to Google Play too.

Get that fixed, and LePan II with ICS would be outstanding, especially for this price. Get that fixed and I would give Le Pan II with ICS 5 stars and highly recommend it to family and friends.

I bought the Le Pan 970 about 2 years ago because (a) it was on sale and (b) it packs a TON of features that I need. This wasn't going to be for average use, I installed it in my car as a music player, GPS, and on occasion digital gauge display for MPH/fuel economy/engine temp/etc. I have it connected to a generic 2A USB charge that is triggered with the key. I use Tasker to control the system by telling it when to sleep/wake up and when the screen should remain on/off. It is subject to severe hot and cold weather, vibration, and is often left for days (sometimes well over a week) in a sleep state with literally no problems at all. It refuses to die or malfunction in any way whatsoever, even without being reset or turned off for months at a time.

The pluses: GPS works great even in bad weather and inside the car. Bluetooth is very stable and connects to my OBDII dongle every time if need be (I have another tablet that handles the gauges 99% of the time, but this serves as a backup). Screen is excellent even in direct sunlight. Even after days on standby the battery never drops below 50%, and quickly charges up even with the screen on full-time and max brightness. Refuses to malfunction or shut-off without my prompting.

The negatives: No Android updates from the manufacturer. Limited aftermarket ROMs. No USB hosting (that I'm aware of). The processor is considered dated, and I have run into stuttering audio while trying to run intensive programs in tandem, although I've only had this happen while trying to run Co-Pilot as my navigation. I switched to Sygic and the problem stopped completely. The camera is rough at best, and the built-in speakers are headache inducing at anything but low volume, although these are common problems with any tablet in this price range and of this age.

I've used several different tablets in my car (Nook Color running various flavors of CM, MID a81e, Lenovo a2107), and because they've all been on the "budget" side of things none of them except for the Le Pan have performed very well. The 970 has not only performed well in terms of performance and stability but gone above-and-beyond my wildest dreams in terms of sheer longevity and tenaciousness.

I've had my ups and downs with this tablet some were my fault absolutely and some that were not. Over all I'd have to agree with what most people say. After having it for a year now I have learned a few things about it and how to get a handle on it, my only big issue with it is the freezing (thank god for that power button and reset hole) but other than that I really do love it. I'm planning on upgrading to the La pan II which seems to have less of a freezing issues and since it's the same product just upgraded, I predict that I will love it as well. And now that the price of Le Pan II seems to have gone down, and Le Pan I costs more now (they stopped production on it), re-selling it to amazon and then buying the new version seems worth while now. And I'd also like access to the Android 4.0 ICS version and some of the apps that are currently unavailable to me. I'm a tech savvy kind of person who can figure out how to make things work well for me, so I've been able to make the Le Pan a very capable product for me, just as well as any other high tier tablets (my Dad has an Ipad and I like my Le pan more as it gives me more freedom and I like the android market more) and it has lots of capabilities for a fraction of the price. So I stand by this one for future use. Of course that does not mean you would feel the same way, I love it for my use, you may feel differently (I recommend trying tablets out first before you buy/keep). I also wanted to share some tips to some people who have had certain issues with the tablet not starting (after the freezing) and having had similar experience I wanted to share a few ways it worked for me. If the reset hole does not work, which happened for me. Here are two things you can do: let the battery drain completely leave it not charging for a day or two (I left it for 4 days because it was fully charged when it happened) and then press reset hole and charge for a day or over night and then when you press the power button (lightly for a sec) you should be able to see that image of a battery that's charging (usually full by this point) if not try pressing reset again now. And it should turn on (after holding the power button for a few sec and waiting for the vibrate, like usual). Now If there is some kind of internal error and you tablet keeps shutting of, or there is a virus (that is why you should always have anti-virus, and yes it can happen) then you should factory reset it. Of course you can go to the settings and do this if you tablet is turning on but if not then: press and hold the volume up (sometimes try down) and the power button together for 15 seconds or so, a screen will come on asking if you want to factory reset (and some other options, there is another reset option you can choose (I forget the name but it's something to do with connection) if says if your android market isn't working properly and you are not able to download and install/update apps) use the volume keys to move up and down and the power button to select which ever option you need. It's a good idea to have a app-back-up app and have it saved to your SD card and Android also has a list of all the apps you have installed in your market. So yeah I have learned all these from experience for quite a while now, in most cases it is just some minor shock the system got and everything works after one of these methods. Now if none of these method work for you then either your power button is broken (if this is the case the reset hole should still work for you), your screen isn't working, or you've some kind of internal damage, these are usually caused by shock or dropping. Dropping/jolting is the worst thing you can do with these things so investing on a good case (with shock resistance too maybe) will help you in the long run. Avoid keeping it in bad temperature as well, like leaving it in you car in a hot/cold day and of course avoid getting it wet. I hope this helps everyone facing these issues. Le Pan is good about re-pairing/replacing if none of these methods work for you which is covered with in their warranty if outside of the warranty try just taking to their support they tend to be pretty helpful (at least they were for me). Good luck!

I have had this tablet for 10 days now.  So far I am impressed.  I've had a first generation iPad since it was first released and my cell phone is an iPhone 4.  This tablet performs better (CPU speed and memory) than my iPad which crashes frequently since the last iOS upgrade. Side by side, there is no noticeable difference between the screen size, image quality, brightness, contrast, etc. between the two devices.  It came with Android 4 (Ice Cream Sandwich).  I have not rooted it, side loaded any applications, or tinkered with it in any way.  In the 10 days I have had it, I have charged the battery twice. I use the device 1.5 to 2 hours a day.  I also purchased a 32GB SD Micro memory card bringing the total memory to 40GB.

I have some movies in MV4 format that I play on the the iPad.  I copied these to the SD card.  At first a message popped up saying it didn't know how to play the MV4 file.  I changed the extensions to MP4 and they play perfectly.  If you haven't heard of HandBrake, Google it.  It's a nice tool to convert DVDs to files that play on portable devices.

I easily configured both my Gmail and corporate Microsoft Exchange mail accounts.

All the images I have stored in Picasa Web Albums magically appeared in the photo gallery.

I have downloaded dozens of apps from Google Play and/or the Amazon app store.  All run just fine.

It found and connected to my wireless router with ease.  It shows a half dozen other wireless routers (my neighbors I assume) which neither my iPhone nor iPad detect.

Pros: Has a camera, SD Slot, HDMI output (which I will probably never use), auto brightness adjustment.

Cons: Volume button is difficult to find.  Google Play doesn't have as many apps as the Apple App Store and there aren't as many Android apps specific to tablets as there are for iPads.

Summary: For ~$250 (including the SD card) I got a great performing tablet with 40GB of storage which is comparable if not better than the 16GB iPad for which I paid $600.  I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because of the volume button and because it did not come with headphones.

Side note: I purchased the Blurex leather case/stand for the Le Pan II and it fits perfectly.

UPDATE: I have now had three solid months of use out of the LePan. I have had NO PROBLEMS with it other than some of my dislikes from my ealier post. Since writing my initial post, my son (3 years old) watched movies which we transfered over from our computer for much of our 10 hour trip to Ireland (waiting in airports and flights) and it still had about 30% battery life with no additional charging needed. I am sure running wifi and bluetooth would significantly reduce this. Looking for a cheap tablet for entertainment and that you don't mind your kids using, this is one way to go.

I have found the apps in the android market for word processing are a little clunky and unfortunatley as a teacher in a school that uses Microsoft Word, the interchange is not so smooth all the time. I can work much quicker (editing, creating, inserting tables, diagrams, etc) using my Lenovo ThinkPad and therefore have not actually used the tablet for work.

Initial Reivew (First Few Weeks):
Picked this up as a Cyber Monday Week deal from Amazon ($150). Purchased this for more of an entertainment tablet, but still to do a little work email/word processing, etc. Price went back up to $250. I would imagine price will keep dropping after December.

Pros:
- Cost
- Netflix, Facebook, and other apps work great
- Came with ICS installed
- Easy work around to download and install Adobe Flash Player
- Solid build for a cheap tablet
- Bluetooth and wifi works as good if not better than my iphone 4, no problems so far as others report.
- Easy connection to computer through bluetooth direct connect and also through supplied transfer cable.
-
Not good/Not Bad:
- Battery Life (not the same as other tablets, but I adjusted the setting and can get 6 hours or so of heavy use -- wifi, websurfing, bluetooth (keyboard), netflix and email no problem. But for my needs, I can't imagine needing 6 hours of heavy use very often with out being able to plug in and charge.

Cons:
- No USB port for plugging in keyboard, USB flash drive, etc. (This was big for me, but have quickly gotten use to the fact that I need to use work arounds).
- Tablet WON'T charge connected to USB port in computer.
- Hard to find case (see below) and the cases I could find were more expensive compared to same brand for ipad.
- Costly replacement cable, planning on being very careful of mine.

Note: BEWARE of keyboard/case combinations that Amazon links with the LePan. I read many reviews before buying and many of them either do not work or need modifications. I purchased the Kensington Universal Pro Keyfolio (bluetooth) case and keyboard. A little costly but I have been very happy with this addition. Had it set up in minutes and my tablet works great with all ports/buttons open while fitting snug in the tabs. Maybe not as snug as other brands, but I have not had any slippage or felt uncomfortable with it. It is also easy to pop out when you want just the tablet. Highly recommend this purchase with the LePan.

We purchased 2 of these tablets, one for each child. One of the two arrived with the power button already missing (rattling around inside the unit). We sent that back to Amazon for a quick and painless replacement.

The other broke, again the power button, 6 months later. We sent that one back to Vizio/LePan under the 1 year warranty. I was only expecting them to find/replace the missing power button, but instead they sent a brand new unit as a replacement.

If you Google this tablet, you find that it is common for the button to fall off (fall inside) because it is note attached to anything, just held in place by the front/back panel pressure. It seems that they have fixed this in later models, so maybe the problem is no longer an issue...

If not for the button, I would give this tablet 5 stars. As it is, the excellent warranty (1 year) and the fact that LePan honors it, gives the table a strong 4 stars.

About the tablet itself:

The size is just a tick bigger than an iPad (my wife has an iPad). I would argue that the added size makes it easier for the kids to hold to. I also like the camera-like wrist strap that comes with it (optional to install). We have put the straps on and tell the kids to keep the strap around their wrist to avoid accidentally dropping.

The screen is the right size for a media tablet. The display is outstanding; it is much better than the iPad. Very bright and the colors pop.

The cpu can get a little taxed when trying to do too many things at once (e.g. download apps and play a game or video at the same time). Most of the time (95%) is has plenty of power for everything that the kids use it for (games, e-mail, video, internet, etc.).

The TC 970 Is a great device, so long as you can live with its flaws. (And it does have them) this device is very prone to Freezing. There is a reset button on the back of the device under power that will get you running again.

Sometimes you might run into an issue with it freezing if you connect it to your pc (Also Your PC will not charge your device it must be from the 2.0A wall charger an ipad charger outputs about the same and a ipad cable can work if you shave down alittle of the plastic sides ON THE END OF THE CABLE not the device alternatively inside the power jack on the lepan there is a tiny metal tab that you can bend back and the normal ipad cable will fit without shaving anything.) If you go under settings/application/development and check mark (Stay Awake) that should stop it from freezing from usb to pc hookup.

Some users have had the device go to sleep and not want to turn back on (Sometimes the lepan needs you to press and hold the power button the hit the reset before releasing the power) under settings/display/screen timeout set it to 30 minutes and put it to sleep manually.

For those of you who now have a paper weight (Device won't turn on no matter what and you're out of warranty) this device seems to have a weak battery jack. My lepan was second hand and I was having all sorts of issues (Device was freezing it would not charge fast/right had problems turning on etc.) I decided just to check the battery. So I got a little Philips head and flat head screw driver (Under the micro sd tab THERE ARE TWO SCREWS THAT MUST BE REMOVED carefully disconnect the back cover from the lepan I find the far end (Away from the power button) to be the easiest place for me to start (The hold switch and volume key can come out so be careful) the battery jack is located on the side the power button is. Mine must have come loose in transit it was a full quarter inch out of the socket after pushing it back in and putting a small piece of electrical tape over it my Lepan worked much better did not freeze as much charged and power on like it was suppose to.

I don't know why this device freezes so much. It does seem related to the wifi in some way, does not freeze nearly as much with wifi turned off. Anyway I hope this review helps some fellow Le Pan TC 970 users, most of this info comes from me spending hours searching through forums.

I give this product a one star rating because -5 is not available. The tablet showed up from Amazon, and it seemed to do okay for about two months (30-days after the 30-day Amazon warranty expired). I took a chance on this tablet, know this device could be unstable, but I knew I wasn't going to use it very often. As it turns out, I did begin to depend upon it greatly, 6-months after my purchase, it just stopped working. I called Amazon and they referred me to the manufacturer.

First things first, let's get the tablet review out of the way. As I said, it seemed to do okay the first 2-months, and then it became unstable. I understood that this operating system was not upgradable to Gingerbread, and I was okay with that.
When I say it was unstable, I mean it lost internet connection frequently, forced closing apps, browser issues, etc. I understand that apps can be unstable on any device, but the most annoying was how it would lose internet connection from my Wi-Fi every time I used it. I would have to go through an 8-step series of steps to get back to where I was on the internet after losing connection. My daughter who also has an Android tablet (EVO view) did not suffer the same issues while using her tablet at the very same time. During the time I have owned this device, I have had to perform over five factory reboots.

Let's say you were okay with the fact it is a low quality device, maybe you think "well, it's less than $200, you get what you pay for", you would be right! The only problem with this is that the customer service for LePan, which is who Amazon referred me to after explaining that there was a manufacturer alert for this product, is equally as unstable as the device they manufacture! I am still not sure why Amazon does not send out alerts on the products you purchase from them, after all, they send you everything else under the that have nothing to do and sometimes everything to do with products you purchase from them.

Anyway, Amazon gave me the customer service number to contact LePan, and it took several phones to get through the first time. It was an automated voice recording (not a touch-system), and either it would re-loop the recording over and over again an insane number of times (in English, as well as Spanish), and the finally putting you out of misery by hanging up on you. You should know that during my time dealing with them for three weeks now, I have had repeated situations like this occur.

At first, when getting a hold of a human, I explained what was transpiring and they referred me to their web site to fill out a claim form. The only problem with this is that my tablet no longer worked and I did not have access to the internet anymore! The representative explained that the device would have to be replaced, and that I would have to arrange and pay for the return of this device. Just so you are aware and you do not heed the advice in this post, it was over $26 to ship.

The first night of making contact with them, my daughter came by with her laptop so I could set up a case to begin the process or the line of communication so I thought. It has been three weeks now, and I still do not have a replacement tablet. I found out through UPS (who are just as bad as LePan), that they had in fact delivered the defective tablet to LePan on the 10th, and still no tablet or sign of a tablet. I have written numerous times within their case system. So far, my inquiries have been met with either silence or silly questions like, "what is your shipping address", and in todays phone message "we have some more questions". You should know that when I filled out a case, I put in my shipping address, when I shipped the device back; it was tied to an RMA, which included my shipping address. When I shipped the device back, I included a manifest that contained my RMA, the Case # and my (drum roll please) .... Shipping Address!

Your take away from this should be: Do not purchase this product because it is poorly manufactured and the vendor is irresponsible and unreliable.

You should know that I do not have a negative view against everyone and everything. I am a little baised towards UPS and prefer Fed-Ex or USPS. I purchased from Amazon because of their liberal return policy. DO NOT COUNT ON THAT FOR THIS PRODUCT. I will still purchase from Amazon, but I will try to purchase the more expensive products in person, locally. I have recently purchased and IPad 2 that I am really loving now. The gentleman at the Apple store was knowledgeable and my experience there was a delight.

I am exhausted, but I will keep you up to date. Thanks for reading and I hope this helps.

Ok, so a couple of weeks back I picked one of these up for a buck thirty, right here.  A few days later, it listed for a buck fifty!  And now, a buck eighty?!  I mean, yeah, the tablet's actually pretty good (for a second-tier FroYo unit), but with its current price volatility, you might want to consider either other models or other vendors.

As for specs, this one is a PDF reader's dream.  Well, ok, a 15" borderless unit would be perfect, but realistically, this is quite a solid runner-up, and a bargain (at least at its former price).  Yeah, it'll play video games, but remember, it runs FroYo (Android 2.2), so the OS is old, and I have no inclination to try upgrading it.  Frankly, I don't even see a need to root it.  If you just consider it a giant Kindle with the Google Play store installed, you'll be pleased as punch with it.  With the current incarnation of Adobe's PDF reader app, if you set the page-view to "Continuous," there's no need to reflow anything.

Other than the occasional freeze or lockup, which frankly happens to all 2nd-tier units at some time or another, the only real issue I've encountered (and I think this may be the issue in some of the negative reviews here) is that you ABSOLUTELY HAVE TO charge the battery fully before using it.  It comes a bit precharged, and the battery life is great (which probably explains the heaviness), but if you let the power run all the way down, the thing won't power up enough to even start a proper recharge cycle for like an hour.  It's a PITA, but the fix is easy--just don't ever let the battery level drop below ~15%.  And speaking of charging, it takes quite a while, and the socket's proprietary, but rumor has it you can use a standard 15-pin iPod charging cable, if you shave off a bit of plastic from the sides.  I've never tried, but honestly, LePan sells replacement cords for so cheap, why bother?

Other things:  Remember, it's running FroYo, so NO EQUALIZER.  (Sux if you're an audiophile.)  Also, it'll fit an iPad case just fine, but the I/O holes and button spaces won't line up, so be prepared to use a scissors on the case if you go this way.

So in a nutshell, for a buck-thirty, LePan's TC-970 is a great PDF reader.  At its buck-eighty inflated price, though, you might as well check out some 1st-tier tabs that run 4.0+ (Ice Cream Sandwich, Jellybean, etc.).

The reason I gave it 4 stars, and am returning it is that it will not connect to my home wifi.

The following is a brief description of my efforts, and conclusion written for any fellow techno geeks as kind of a courtesy: I have Clear (formally Clearwire) for my home ISP. I use a combination box from Clear that serves as both the tranceiver, and wireless router. It works fine with my laptops, Kindle Fire, and Ipod. I tried two different encryption protocols AND open (unsecured). In each case I got my laptop back on the internet, but could not get the Le Pan II tablet to communicate with the wifi network. (The Le Pan II continually cycles between "connecting", & "searching".)  I tried both with automatic settings, and manually entering static network IP address, and several IP addresses that were open, and in the range of the Clear device. My conclusion (best guess) of the culprit is the MAC address which the Le Pan ii uses to identify itself. According to tech support at Clear (and my own searching through the Clear tranceiver/router settings) there is no way to turn off or alter it's filtering for MAC addresses. Which I read is possible on other wifi routers (Lynksys for example.)If anyone has a better theory, I welcome the input in response to this review to aid any future buyers of this tablet that may have similar difficulty.

I also want to say Amazon customer service was absolutely a dream come true. I talked to a lady on the phone last night, and she authorized my return with great compassion, and understanding. As a result I have already placed an order from Amazon for a different tablet (Asus TF300) which I am hopeful will not have the issue I experienced with the Le Pan II.

This is the third tablet I've purchased, largely on the strength that it's Google certified against the Play store.  I had an Acer Iconia that I wound up giving to my father in law.  I purchased a Nook Tablet and returned it after a week.  This?  It's actually replaced the numerous laptops and Kindles around the domicile as my primary information consumption device.  It's not perfect.  Sometimes Flash buffering is quirky, and there are a number of apps that just plain don't work, usually obscure games I don't care about.  I really miss having Swype, which is apparently incompatible due to the screen form factor.  I think in the end, why I like it so much is because of the form factor.  9.7 inches is just right for holding in one hand while having easy readability and UI spacing, and it's all without Apple's suffocating user experience.  The biggest advantage over the 7" form factor?  PDFs.  I go to a lot of conferences with materials in PDF format, and seven inches is not going to cut it.  I move documents and e-books into my Dropbox on any PC and it opens with zero fuss seconds later.  Try that with iOS.  I've had an iPhone, Android phones, and even a terrible XP tablet at work back in the day.  Using this is a pleasure, and you get a lot of bang for your buck.

UPDATE 7/30/2012
Upgraded to the official Android 4.0.4 release a couple of weeks ago.  Still have access to the Google Play store, and still pleased as punch.  It runs somewhat faster, battery life lasts a LOT longer, and a number of app issues that existed under Honeycomb have been fixed.  A free Swype analogue is too be had with TouchPal Keyboard.  I've been comparing it to the iPad 2s some folks have at work, and wouldn't trade it for a second.  The advantage of DropBox and its local LAN sync plus custom third party apps over the iOS world really cannot be overstated.

Began researching tablets when the Kindle came out and set the new low for price points. Decided I preferred the 10inch form factor.  Wasn't really sure where a tablet fit in my gadget lifestyle, but felt like there was a need for something more mobile and travel friendly. Didn't want to spend a lot because I know I will want a lightweight laptop for more intense tasks.

Evaluated and dismissed Xoom and Galaxy.  Really, really like the Asus 300t and the Prime. Just didn't want to invest that much.  Started searching the sub 300 price point and the Le Pan came up with solid reviews on Amazon.  Originally had the 970 briefly but returned because the single core just couldn't handle the streaming media job that was one of my key uses.

The Le Pan II fits the bill perfectly for me.  It's very affordable, especially given the power it has.  The dual core on this device makes it quite snappy. The touch screen is extremely responsive. It has been my constant companion for days.  It is very very usable for note taking with Evernote and a Logitech Bluetooth KB, it does Amazon Prime and Netflix without any jerkiness or blocky video.  Basically, it has more than enough processing power to meet my needs. Wireless performs as well as any laptop or iPad in my house.  The speed of the GUI is as fast or faster than the iPad 1. I don't have an iPad 2 or 3 to compare to.

The device is HoneyComb out of the box. Rumors of ICS abound and Le Pan has promised the update, but it hasn't surfaced as yet. Not a deal breaker for me, as the Honeycomb interface is quite usable and tablet oriented apps are emerging, so it's not just big goofy phone resolution.

One thing I would like to see fixed on it with ICS is the Bluetooth stack.  It could be just the Logitech KB I am using, but I have a connection issue.  Basically, I have to completely reboot the tablet to get it to connect.  When the device times out to save power or I turn the screen off, I can re-connect, but it won't stay connected. I don't have to re-pair, but I have to reboot.  It seems as though the KB is waiting for a response that the tablet only gives the first time they connect after a reboot.  Could be the KB too for that matter. At any rate, works just fine as long as I reboot.  As long as I keep using it periodically, as I do when I take notes at work throughout the day.  It works fine.

Battery power is good, not great.  It will last around 8-9 hours using Bluetooth and wireless, but just barely.  It's a good idea to keep your very lightweight Le Pan plug handy.  Yes, it's a 30 pin proprietary job, but it works fine and they do have an HDMI out attachment you can buy.  I don't have much interest in that though.

Note about the 9.7 inch form factor.  I have liked the 9.7 size since the iPad. It feels a touch more comfortable to me than the 10.1.  Be advised that widescreen video tends to look better on the 10.1 or even on an iPad since video is often formatted to that device.  That said, I have NO issue watching movies on my Le Pan.  I don't mind letterbox look, MX Player let's me play with how much I fill the screen. Most streaming video uses the screen real estate well, and finally I can format any mobile video to fit the screen perfectly as I see fit. Generally I just format for iPad using Handbrake and it looks great.

I use a Logitech Bluetooth KB for Android devices with this tablet. I use the Blurex Leather Folio case made for the Le Pan I and II. I like both.

Bottom Line:  Very powerful tablet for a very low price. While I haven't had it long, I think the build quality is excellent and will hold up. If things break down, I will definitely update my review.  I have recommended to several friends. I love this tablet!

I have to start off by saying that this is the first tablet I have ever owned.  I have played with many tablets at the store and with friends, but this is the first one I ever bought and owned.

In my opinion, this is the best tablet for the price.  It comes equipped with Android 3.2 Honeycomb, and it is a joy to use.

I would advice getting a case or something to prop it up a bit, it makes typing much more enjoyable.
The battery life is good, lasting anywhere from 5 to 8 hours of continual use, maybe more if wifi is turned off.
It has 8GB of memory built in, with up to 32GB via a micro SD card.

This is more than fast enough for my needs, which are internet browsing, streaming movies, Youtube, some online shopping, etc...
I am not a real techy person, and probably don't use 90% of what this tablet can do, but for me it is perfect.

Now, for some of the negative reviews you may have heard.  Yes, the company that makes this tablet is rather shady in my opinion.  They don't seem to follow through with their promises, however there is some light at the end of the tunnel.

I was able to join a very useful forum at [...]
There are some great people over there who are dedicated to making the most out of this tablet, and it's predecessor, the TC970.
As of today, the company has not released Android 4.0 ICS for this device, like they said they would.  They have also not released any of the information necessary for private developers to do what they do to make custom versions of ICS for this device.  However, through that forum that I mentioned, there seems to be some headway being made, it is starting to look like the company is going to be releasing ICS any day now.
In my opinion, ICS is not that much of an improvement over Honeycomb, but the point is that the company made it seem like this device would be easily up-gradable to ICS, and it is easily up-gradable, but they have to release the OS for us to upgrade to.

There also seem to be some issues with people not having HDMI output available, and a lack of accessories for this device, but all in all, I have not been bothered by those things.

There are some people who have wifi issues with this device, I am not one of them.  My device has worked flawlessly everywhere I have tried to get a wifi signal.

There are some issues with this device and the Youtube app buffering constantly.  This was taken care of for me by updating the flashplayer, and by getting a wireless-n router.  This device seems to like that router better, it was a cheap $30 router that I got.  I will say that it makes sense for the youtube app to need a lot of bandwith to function properly.  The resolution for HD videos on this device rivals my desktop screen.

This review is for those people who are simply looking for a tablet to use to browse the internet, watch some movies, and play some games.
The Google Play market is awesome, tons of free apps, and some really great paid ones as well.  If you are an uber geek/techy person, this product will probably not be for you.  I can easily see someone like that getting frustrated that they can't have the latest and greatest OS right away.  For me, Honeycomb is polished and clean, and a joy to use.  So if ICS never comes out for this tablet it's not a big deal to me.
I do think the people at the forum will eventually be able to get all the information they need to start making customer software for this device to help it perform even better, but even right out of the box it is great.

I added a 32 gb sd card (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004G60AD6/ref=oh_details_o06_s00_i00) which works out fine for adding movies, music and pictures. The LePan 2 does not allow apps to be loaded on the extra sd card however, or maybe I just have not figured out how to do this yet.

I bought the Targus case (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005BZNE1Q/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00) which works great, but is a little thick and heavy. I use it around the house, but when traveling I use a very simple neoprene Ipad sleeve I got on Ebay for 4 bucks.

As a screen protector I use this: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003D8GAA0/ref=oh_details_o04_s00_i00. It comes with three protectors that do need some trimming. The protector does apply very easily without bubbles as long as you clean the screen very well with the cleaning cloth that comes with the Lepan. The protector is quite thick but I have not noticed any delays on the touch screen after adding this.

All in all I have thoroughly enjoyed the LePan 2 tablet so far to browse the internet, watch movies and TV shows online, stream Netflix, Pandora and play some games I found on the Google Marketplace. If you are in doubt, give it a chance. It's a great tablet for the price.

In this short evolution it has gone from a thing that I loved to a thing that I now hate.  I'm not even considering contacting the manufacturer because it's long out of warranty by now, and I don't want to compound my frustration by trying to deal with a non-responsive vendor's non-existent Customer Service--another frequent complaint about this tablet.

I'm glad I held off on reviewing it when it was new so I wouldn't have to retract everything later.  Unfortunately, a  few months ago I recommended it to my father, who had ruined his third computer by always shutting it off before the anti-virus program could update and finish running and removing viruses (he wanted to "save money" on electric bills).  So now I've got him playing "Tablet Roulette" with this unreliable Le Pan TC970, too.  I can no longer feel guiltless recommending this tablet to anyone.

Also, what I feel is a generic problem with the Android operating system is the whole philosophy of open source application development--nearly all the available apps continually launch themselves, hogging memory and other resources (and probably spying on your activity) which requires another app (a Task Killer) to free up the tablet so it can continue to run relatively smoothly.  I wouldn't be the least bit surprised to hear any day now that the Android operating system is a growing favorite target for hackers to develop viruses, worms, Trojan Horses, etc. to harass the unsuspecting public for "fun."

I'm almost tempted to fork out the money for the IPad just to get away from this situation, but I'll need to do more research to see if they don't also experience some of the same problems...

Upon activating the tablet after it's been in standby mode for a while, the touchscreen becomes essentially non-functional for several minutes.  For example, after activating from standby and reaching the unlock screen with a pattern, I tried numerous times trying to swipe the correct pattern.  However, for some reason, the touchscreen would never "maintain" the line I tried drawing while swiping over the circles.  The line would always "breakup" before I could finish the pattern for 4 circles.  It seemed to be skipping from one circle to the next without any continuous connection.  This happened for about 5 minutes, until it finally read my finger swipe correctly and unlocked.  Frustrated, I decided to try a password lock instead of a pattern.  So I put the tablet on standby for a while, reactivated it, and tried putting in my password via the keyboard.  However, whenever I pressed a key, it would read it as double, sometimes even triple (e.g. pressing the 'd' key once, would result in 'dd' or 'ddd' being entered into the password field).  This happened with all the other keys I pressed, and continued for several minutes, until it stopped doing it all of a sudden and was finally able to put in my password.  Frustrated again, I turned off any lock.

However, not being able to control the unlock screen with finger swipes wasn't the only issue after returning from standby.  Whenever I tried to use pdfs after returning from a long standby, I could not control scrolling or zooming.  Anytime I tried scrolling, it would zoom in and out.  This would continue for several minutes until it would finally function normally.
So it's pretty clear that with my tablet, something happens to the touchscreen functionality after it's been in standby for a while.  I always had to wait several minutes after activating from standby for the touchscreen to work properly.  The touchscreen keyboard must be "reloading" during that time, or something.  But yea, this is unacceptable for me.  I tried doing a factory reset as well as downloading the new firmware, but it still kept giving me the same problem.  I really wanted to enjoy this tablet since everything else works decently, but this one major flaw with the touchscreen has led me to return this tablet.

As of writing, this tablet now supports CyanogenMod7, which is Android 2.3. (Gingerbread). By contrast, the stock ROM comes with Android 2.2 (Froyo), which is still acceptable but obviously suboptimal for a tablet that can run something better. A brief Google search will get you started. I was able to switch everything over in about an hour. Second, the battery life for this thing is amazing. I charge it so infrequently that I'm often taken aback by how much power it's not using in between charges. I can't even remember the last time I had to plug it in, though I tend to charge it up anyway just in case the zombie apocalypse happens while I'm at work and I need to locate safe houses on my way to the capitol or something. Anyway, if you're looking for a tablet that can do better than "maybe 6 hours on a single charge if you're lucky", this is the way to go. Other pros include surprisingly powerful speakers, good Wi-fi reception even with a low signal, an acceptable screen for the price, and so on. Although I wouldn't say it's designed specifically to be ergonomic, it's still comfortable to hold. Pretend it's a Dualshock for maximum grip comfort. Not much to say when it comes to negatives. Since it's not Honeycomb, actual made-for-tablet-app support is somewhat spotty. About half of my apps notice it's a tablet anyway. The other half just run in regular mode. I've yet to have this be a big issue, but I do wish I could use all the new tablet apps out there. Other than that, the glossy screen smudges easily, which is what you signed up for when you get a tablet in general I suppose. I considered getting a tablet for a while, but have never been someone who rushes into the "latest fad" in electronics. Last December I saw my kids at Christmas and my DIL had an iPad2. It was nice, but way too pricey for me, however I did like the features it offered and was looking for something similar without the proprietary connections Apple requires. After much reading and learning, I stumbled upon the Le Pan II. It seemed to have everything I wanted without the huge cash outlay required by some other manufacturers. I ordered mine March 9th and received it April 2nd. I've waited to write a review to give myself time to familiarize myself with most of the things that can be done with this tablet. So far I have used Gmail, Hotmail, YouTube, Twitter, Skype, Facebook, several games (Pirates Of The Caribbean - Master of the Seas, AirAttack, TV and Movie trivia games, etc), Flixster, Regal, Google World and at least two drawing apps plus numerous other miscellaneous apps which are available for free. I've downloaded apps from getjar, Google Play and the Amazon Android market. I've changed the wallpaper, created, configured and changed my notification ringtone from a MP3 file. I've listened to music, radio and police/fire scanners and used the GPS module. I've formatted and installed two different 32gb microSD cards with no problems and transferred data (music and photos) again with no problems. In other words I think I have tried and tested just about every thing this tablet has to offer. All with few to no problems (had one small problem with a Hotmail app, but I changed it to an older version and have had no other problems except my lack of tablet experience). I've connected to 3 different wifi routers (home and two more on the go). I also contacted the Le Pan support site. Emailed them from their website over a weekend (on a Sunday), received a reply Monday morning. Request was filled within two days (I ordered an extra USB cable and charger plug). I received them today (April 17) and they even sent me an extra wrist strap at no extra charge. No issues with the tablet which required any further support. I got a CaseCrown black tablet case (currently unavailable) as well as a soft-sided sleeve from Disney and the Armorsuit screen protectorArmorSuit MilitaryShield - Le Pan II Screen Protector Shield with Lifetime Replacements. It protects the screen from scratches and minimizes the fingerprints as well as making it easier to wipe them off when they do occur. Tablet feels solid, well-built, sturdy and between many of the reviews and posts here, as well as YouTube, and the Lepanlife forum, plus a friend I made via the review comments if I had a question I found the answer in short order. A huge thank you to all those who took the time to write lengthy reviews about this tablet and post videos. My tablet came with Baseband v. 118 which appears to have solved most of the problems people had in the past. The only thing I haven't tried yet is Bluetooth because I do not have any Bluetooth accessories to test. Frankly, the keyboard (while it does take a little getting used to) is adequate for typing. No, I cannot type as fast on it as I would a full size keyboard, but it's good enough for now. At some point I may get one with Bluetooth, but for now I couldn't be happier. I got everything I wanted for almost half the cost of a similarly configured tablet and mine has (basically) unlimited storage capabilities via the 32gb microSD cards. If I need more storage, I just buy another card.

In sum, if you are looking for the cheapest tablet that is decent, reliable & all the bells & whistles, this is the one for you.

First, for it's price this is a pretty decent tablet. However, price is not all that matters with these things and it really depends on what you use it for and overall quality.

I don't regret the purchase, but people who are used to consumer ready products and don't like to hack, figure things out, etc should stick with Galaxy or iPad.

Advantages:
- Great price
- Solid quality

Disadvantage:
- Lack of accessories. Even basic ones such as USB OTG or HDMI connector.
- Touchscreen sometimes has trouble with pattern unlock (this may be more my product or my fingers though)
- Lacks back camera (I didn't think this would be a problem, but it's something I would like to see). I knew this buying it though and it's negated with the price.

General:

This is very well built. I'm pleased with the way it feels and it works as I expected (if you have an android phone, it's basically a big giant phone). I had no problems installing Android Applications. Any disadvantages with the software are inherent with the software and not with the tablet.

The manufacturer's website is very sparse with information. If you want any significant information you have to search for it and find what others have to say about it.

Performance:
I use it mostly for PDF reading. It's pretty slow for large files on any number of reading devices. However, it displays small files very well. I use it for double column journal articles and it's big enough (for me) to read it in "fit screen mode." This is true of both Adobe Reader, Aldiko, and one other reader I forgot the name of and have since uninstalled.

I installed an unofficial version of VLC player (noneon version) and it works great. No complaints there.

Software:

It's pretty bare... but that's how I like it. Unlike my Samsung Epic 4G, it's not filled with bloatware and I can install many of them.

This is a big plus for me and I've installed all the applications I normally like without any bugs.

Applications (known) that I use that work great: Google Voice, Skype, Kindle Reader, Aldiko, Facebook, Firefox, eBay, VLC, Tivo, Wikipedia.

The Adobe Reader does strange things when you change stretch/zoom in view settings. For me, if I change it while reading a PDF it escapes out and goes back to the main adobe file selection screen. This may be software though.

Networking:

It doesn't accept ad hoc connection (unless you root it). I found out this is common to most mobile devices not just Le Pan. The device doesn't seem to have a problem finding my network at home but it does seem to have a hard time finding new networks when I go to Starbucks, Barnes and Nobles, etc (or other restaurant with free Wifi). It's not a huge problem, but it takes a while to find new networks.

Bluetooth is slow... It's slower transferring files than my Samsung Epic 4G and a Treo. However, I don't do much with Bluetooth anyway and the mouse I installed works fine and was easy to install.

Accessories:

Horrible support. This is a relatively new product and it's not from one of the big manufacturers, but it misses some of the basic accessories that they should have made pre-launch. I can say this because I'm an electrical engineer and I've checked their the circuit diagram they submitted to FCC,... there should be no reason they shouldn't have had their HDMI adapter ready at launch.

Does not have a 30-pin connector to USB connector. I would have liked to see them come out

Also, regarding accessories, they are difficult to find. You have to send an e-mail to customer support and pay $10 shipping to receive a cable.

Their products aren't compatible with any other tablet device. Some iPod chargers work if you shave a piece of plastic off though.

Summary:

Overall, if you can do without the HDMI or connecting to external USB devices this is an excellent product. The company promises to bring these out, but many new companies break promises. With the Le Pan TC970, they said it would be upgradeable to Honeycomb and now they say it will not be available.

I give the lepan tc970 5 stars because of quality and functionality vs value. First of all, I got this tablet for my wife for christmas so we have had plenty of time to get a very good feel for it. Secondly, between my wife, myself and my 4 year old son this tablet gets used on average about 5 hours a day. It comes pre installed with official android market aka (google play) and adobe flash player(It also upgraded to the newest version through the market). The build quality is excellent, it looks and feels like a brand name device. We use it as a daily driver and I find it to be nicer than my cousins Ipad 1. It is mostly the little things like I HATE typing in stuff. We talk to our phones, we talk to our xbox 360 and we talk to our tablet. Today we were at a family birthday party and While holding my 1 year old I came to the realization that it is very annoying to have to try and type on her ipad with 1 hand like a caveman to do a simple google or youtube search rather than just press the mic button and speak what we want to search for, and THEN the ipads browser brings up what appears to be a "youtube app" like on a phone rather than the actual website like our laptop and our lepan do. I Know several people with ipad 1-2,new Ipod touch, hp touchpad and other android tablets so I have had lots of time to play with them all to my hearts content. The physical build quality of the lepan is on par with those tablets. It plays angry birds, netflix, hbo go, crackle, skype video chat(more about that in the cons), facebook, youtube(it plays most of these both in the browser or as an app, except netflix which requires silverlight for in browser playback). The only game I found that it wasn't fast enough to play flawlessly was gta3, which it plays but with hesitation and not perfectly smooth(I have made it to the second part of the city after they reopen the broken bridge). Pretty much it does what you would expect a full fledged tablet to do.

CONS ..all of these are well documented and fairly common..REGARDING THE FREEZING EVERYONE IS TALKING ABOUT....(as well as a couple other things)
The few problems the tablet has are obviously related to minor bugs in the firmware which could potentially be fixed with a simple update once it's available from lepan(they have released 3 updates since we have had it so at least they are supporting it).

1. It didn't take me long to figure out that(at least in my case) the tablet didn't like us to let it's screen go to sleep ON ITS OWN while it was in the middle of STREAMING OR DOWNLOADING VIA WIFI. It froze once while streaming pandora and once while downloading the extra game content for gta3(both times it froze the exact instant that the screen went to sleep). To remedy this I simply set the screen sleep timer in settings to the highest value(30 min i think) and when we are done using the tablet we put it to sleep manually by pressing the power button. We have not found this to be a hassle because it kind of comes naturally to turn a device off when you are done using it. ........Since we have done this we have had no more problems whatsoever with the tablet freezing........(I did this about 2 months ago)

*****edit. we are currently using update build number 4626 and today I tested it according to c.s. instructions in the tablet page discussions and even after turning the screen sleep timer back down I could not get it to freeze again. This morning I asked my wife when the last time was that it froze on her and she said it has never froze while she was using it. It has also never froze on my son, so apparently it only happened to me the couple times when we first got it and I was downloading alot of apps and games and setting everything up. I don't know if it was the 4626 update that permanently fixed it or what but I do know that I have been trying to get it to freeze on purpose and can't get it to do it again.*****

2. Skype video chat works perfectly with the skype app that is available on the market BUT the first time you run it the screen will flicker strangely, leave the video call running and toggle the video on and off in between flickers, after doing this a couple times(may take around 30 seconds) it will find the right video settings and work properly. This only needs done the one time(unless you flash a new firmware or do a factory reset) Every time you use skype video after this it will work perfectly as expected. I skyped with both a new Ipod touch and a ipad 2, both worked flawlessly on both ends.

3. This is not a big deal but I figured I would mention it anyway. With the stock launcher, the home screens don't auto rotate like they should. It rotates properly in apps and on the web, but not on the home screens. However it works properly when I run "go launcher ex" which is free on the market and I figure most people would want to run a fancy custom launcher regardless. (I didn't even notice the rotation issue until later because I had already planned to run go launcher before we even got it.)

So that is it, if you can't or don't want to spend more than $200, this is the way to go. There is a reason that the tc970 has such high reviews on every site that sells it. It's because it's an excellent device with a beautiful screen, long battery life, pleasing on the eyes design wise, and does every single thing that you would expect of a tablet. You could condemn it for having a couple easily fixable superficial flaws or with a little tlc you could absolutely love it.

ORIGINAL (a couple of days of usage):

My aim was to get a tablet for my toddler to watch kids cartoons and play some simple games. My kid (1.7 y.o) tends to throw stuff on the floor when he gets too irritated, alas the price of the purchase had to be minimized. Le Pan was the cheapest one with a full 10 inch screen, so I thought it would be good enough for the purpose.

I can say that the screen is really good. View angle is excellent, the screen is very bright.

But unfortunately the device is not very usable as it freezes very often for no reason at all. I've connected it to my laptop via USB, uploaded a couple of cartoons. It refused to play most of them, just played the MP4 one.

I've installed BS player and it played FLV ones in software mode which sucked - the cartoon video was kind of slow which caused out of sync with audio.

When I tried to play toons it would sometime freeze in the middle of it, or refused to play it from the start displaying an alert window on top of a garbage video background which could only be removed by restarting the device with Reset button.

And right now it just froze for just no reason.

So, anyway, I think that I will be able to convert all of my kids cartoons to some format that this device could tolerate, and will hope that my kid hits it really hard against the wall in the next couple of months which would justify a purchase of a better one.

Update (June 14th 2012):
Many had problem with this tablet not powering up. I would like to share work-around for that issue, since I experienced it too.
Likely cause: It looks that if you leave battery to drain completely, tablet will not be able to charge properly.
Effect: As a result of above, tablet appears as dead, even if plugged in charger
Work-around: Use reset button (you will need to use something sharp to press it) to reset tablet while plugged in charger. If needed, unplug and plug charger again.

Above works for me, and I can always recover from this issue. Of course, this is kind of annoying, but if you make sure to regularly charge tablet, and not letting it drain completely, it will work just fine. Bottom line is, this is design issue, but I guess it is expected for this kind of product.

I'm going to do something no one else has done. I am going to compare this to an iPad II from a non-technical point of view. Please bear in mind you can buy three of these for the price of one iPad.

Size. This is slightly smaller than an iPad II in exterior dimensions, therefore an iPad II case fits loosely. The width is about the same, but the height is almost a quarter inch shorter. The thickness is about the same. I bought a Targus Truss case for iPad and it does not fit well. I am ordering one for HP Touchpad which according to the reviews will fit better.

Battery. I have not watched movies on either device so I cannot comment on that. However for web surfing they are about the same. My battery app indicates over 10 hours of web surfing time. After yesterday I can testify that is pretty accurate. If you can run the battery down on this then your spending too much time on a tablet. I cannot imagine a situation where you would have to recharge during the day. It stayed right there with the iPad II all day yesterday.

Screen. I cannot tell the difference in the quality of this compared to the iPad II. Yes the screen is shiny and so is the iPad. They both show fingerprints unless you use a stylus. Screen protectors help but I do not like them, no matter how good they are they take away from the quality of the display. The touchscreen is very responsive but did not work well with the stylus. This may be because of the quality of the stylus that I had. I don't know why people complain about shiny screens. They are on all of your phones and all of your tablets. Get over it. They all have the same problems.

Brightness. I compared this to the iPad II while out in the car. You could not see either screen unless you were in the shade. You can see fingerprints on both in the reflection. The iPad might have been a tiny bit brighter. I have the same problem with my phone in bright light. These devices do not work well outdoors. It is a limitation of all devices. Again get over it. The only thing that works outdoors is a Nook or a Kindle with E ink technology.

Screen orientation. There are some apps that will not rotate. I have the same problem on the iPad when there is not an iPad app available and you have to use one for an iPhone. This is not an operating system problem, it is a problem with the app developer. Any developer can develop their app for screen rotation if they want to. The only thing I can say about this product is that the home screen only displays in landscape mode. However, this is the way that most people use a tablet and I don't see why this would be a problem for anyone. I noticed that HBO go and Max go only display the menu in vertical mode. The movies play in landscape mode just like the iPad. This is a minor inconvenience to have to turn the tablet to read the menu. How lazy are we getting?

Speed. This might be a little hard to believe,but I think it is faster than the iPad. My wife uses the iPad more than I do, so I had her watch over my shoulder while I did several tasks and she agreed it is really fast. I am not going to say it is faster than an iPad II, but I think it is.

30 pin connector. While the internal pin connector appears to be the same the exterior housing is different than the iPad. You might be able to force it but why would you do that. I do not know why some reviewers would say that they would work. Le Pan shows them on their website for $4.00. Amazon should offer this cable if they are going to sell this product. I think this is a problem. However, the cable is well made and I do not plan on ordering a replacement.

GPS. The GPS works great. This is not even available on the iPad II with Wi-Fi. You have to get a 3G iPad in order to use GPS or order a separate GPS unit that will work with iPad. The iPad will not connect to a standard Bluetooth GPS. Again, another reason to not like their proprietary software from Apple.

Printing. There are only a few wireless printers that will work with an iPad. Again, because of the proprietary software. All you need with this tablet is an app like Printershare to print to any Wi-Fi printer. Just one more reason not to buy an Apple product.

In short, you can tell I do not like Apple products. They are great product and I wish they were compatible with the rest of the world. I still own an iPad and we love it, but it is the only one I will ever own because it is so limited. I will never own an iPhone because there are so many android options available now.

If you have a MacBook and an iPhone, then you should buy an iPad.

If you have a PC, any other android devices or an android phone then you will probably not be as happy with an iPad as you would be with a nice android tablet. You might like an HP Touchpad, but it is actually more like a laptop and is not an android. I think that for the price this tablet is hard to beat. I think I will continue to use this one for a while then upgrade it to a Le Pan II or III. For right now I am happy with the performance of this tablet. I hope you find this information helpful in making your decision.

I originally bought this tablet in December. Two of them actually, one for each of the kids (10 years old and 13 years old). They had been begging me for a tablet, and I absolutely WOULD NOT pay over $200 for a tablet for a child. So, of course the iPad was out of the question ;-) I had done a TON of research on tablets at or below the $200 price point. I knew that for my tech saavy kids who both have android smart phones and love them, they would need to have something that at least had the "feel" of an iPad with things like great graphics, ability to play tons of games and of course the capacitive touch screen (NOT the resistive). For those of you who have no clue what those things mean (like me when I first started looking at tablets), basically the resistive version requires a harder "push" on the screen to register what the user wants to do and can be used with gloved fingers, stylus' etc. The capacitive ones are the "cool" ones according to my kids, that register the users intended action with a slight touch giving you the nice "flow" when flipping screens, easy launch of apps etc. Really, capacitive vs. resistive is a personal choice. I've used both and have no issues with either one, although I too prefer the capacitive version.

So, after days and days of research, I learned that most of the tablets out there below my afore mentioned price quote had resistive screens instead of capacitive, low memory and had no SD card slot, and did not play well with apps, videos etc. Since the kids use their tablets mostly for game playing and/or video watching while on road trips, those were pretty high up on my list of important functionality.

As other reviewers have mentioned, I too was wary about an new company that I never heard of. After reading all of the pros and cons, I decided that for the price, this tablet would give me the most bang for my buck. Now, almost three months later, I'm EXTREMELY pleased with my decision.

First off, I LOVE LOVE LOVE the look and feel of these tablets. My mother-in-law has an iPad and she let me play with it over Christmas time, and I actually prefer the Le Pan to the iPad in terms of the overall look and feel. I got this tablet for my girlfriend's birthday in February 2012. She has an aging laptop that she used for surfing the web so this is a nice, inexpensive replacement that lets her surf the web, play games and read books, at a fraction of the cost of an iPad or other high end tablet. I have been able to compare the Le Pan with an iPad 2 that I borrowed from work. I have used the iPad for a while now, and the Le Pan has several advantages:

-Price. Can't say more.
-You can load flash websites. It seems with the iPad I have to open up a lot of websites on the computer (online banking, etc never seem to work right)
-More free/cheaper apps. By comparison, apps for iPad tend to be more expensive/fewer free apps available (and the free ones are full of ads)
-Has built-in GPS (haven't used it much)

The Le Pan 970 has some disadvantages:

-It does freeze, it seems everyone has a different experience. This one locks up every few hours, especially if using one program (e.g., reading a book or playing a game) continuously. As others have pointed out, I upgraded the firmware right when I got it but the Le Pan still freezes. She keeps a paper clip handy all the time to reset it. Or, you have to remember to close out of the app you are using periodically, although that is not a guarantee.

-It is not quite as fast as the iPad. Loading websites, zooming in, etc. takes a second or two longer. Maybe the iPad is faster because it ignores the flash content in many websites.

-The camera is backwards. I use Skype with the iPad and it works beautifully, seems with the Le Pan a lot of people report issues.

-It runs the somewhat dated version of Android that according to others, was meant for smartphones. So, a lot of websites open up in the mobile version, which can be annoying.

All in all, a good tablet if you're on the fence and if you are like me and don't want to spend a lot on a tablet--especially considering that for the price of an iPad you can buy quite nice laptop that lets you do a lot more and get work done. But this is a great tablet to check email/facebook/news while eating breakfast, read a book on a boring day at work or play angry birds. But, only 3 stars because of the fairly frequent (about once daily) freezes.

UPDATE August 2012: The freezing got so bad (she had to have a paper clip in hand all the time), she had to send it in to LePan. The customer service is terrible, it took about 6 weeks to get it replaced. 3 Months later, the replaced tablet freezes less often, but still locks up unexpectedly and behaves erratically once/twice a week (apps won't load, websites freeze up) even after rebooting. So, once a month she has to do a factory reset and reinstall everything.

Other than that, I do highly recommend it, I even got one for my mother as a christmas gift. But if Android 2.2 and a single core 1GHZ processor isn't your thing, then a I recommend trying out the Le Pan II, considering the price point and Android Honeycomb and it's ability to be upgraded to Android 4.0 ICS. I have ordered a case for it (a Targus Truss case for the iPad 1) and I will update this review when I get it, also I will be doing a 6 month update as well.

There are 3 major problems with this device:

1) WiFi network issues (also documented by other users on couple of forums)

Most of the time YouTube is unusable, both via dedicated application and the browser. Soon after playback starts it starts buffering and buffering never stops.

Similar problems occur with Netflix and any other apps/processes that require streaming and/or downloads. I observed it even on Google Market where most of the apps are pretty small - download/update starts, then stalls for several minutes at 10-20%, then resumes several minutes later. At the same time 2 other devices on the same WiFi network (laptop and Android phone) exhibit no such issues whatsoever.

2) Lack of official Windows drivers

There are no official Windows drivers available, so when plugged in device is not mapped to the drive letter in Windows Explorer. Other users reported on internet forums that they received email from Le Pan support stating that they will not release drivers to the public.

I emailed support regarding driver availability and received no response at all.

That being said there are unofficial drivers for the previous model of this device (970) that has been hacked to work with LP II. I have not tried them and can't comment on how well they work or if they can be used for doing software development on this tablet which was my intended usage (I am talking about development of regular Android apps that do not require device to be rooted).

3) Source code for OS has not been published. As far as I understand this is a violation of license for Android OS.

I am sending device back mostly because of WiFi problems and lack of drivers. Considering unresponsive support, lack of drivers, root not being achieved and source code not being available I am not holding my breath for WiFi problems to be fixed.

TO FIX WIFI!!!
Look up the MAC address in your tablet settings > about tablet > Status > WiFi MAC address (00:29:c8:00:c1:aa looks something like that)
Then go into your router setup and create a Static DHCP, I used 192.168.0.199 then linked my MAC address to it.
Disconnect and Reconnect your tablets WiFi and when it connects, it should automatically go to the Static DHCP you created.

If you don't understand, look at your router instructions or just do some Googling on setting up a Static DHCP for a Tablet. Worked for me!
